item.title: The Smoking Machine, An Apparatus That Automatically Lights, Smokes, and Tosses Cigarettes on the Ground

item.description: In this video from 2010, The Smoking Machine created by Norway-based Kristoffer Myskja in 2007, works it way through loading, lighting, smoking, and discarding a cigarette. images via Kristoffer Myskja via The Awesomer
item.content:encoded:
In this video from 2010, The Smoking Machine created by Norway-based Kristoffer Myskja in 2007, works it way through loading, lighting, smoking, and discarding a cigarette.

item.description: The Prism Nightlight is a clever light that is turned on and off by pivoting it like a seesaw. The light is a design concept by designer Nicholas Baker. photos via Nicholas Baker via JVNK, Colossal

item.title: Brooke Banker, A New York City Fashion Model with Famously Long Legs
item.dc:creator: EDW Lynch
item.description: New York City model Brooke Banker has made a name for herself with her unusually long legs—her outseam measurement of 47 inches is two-thirds of her overall height of 5 foot 11. Banker talks about her modeling career in this video by Barcroft Media.
item.content:encoded: New York City model Brooke Banker has made a name for herself with her unusually long legs—her outseam measurement of 47 inches is two-thirds of her overall height of 5 foot 11. Banker talks about her modeling career in this video by Barcroft Media.

item.title: The Story, A 1969 Short Film by Homer Groening Starring His Kids Maggie, Lisa, and Matt
item.dc:creator: EDW Lynch
item.description: “The Story” is a charming short film starring Maggie, Lisa, and Matt Groening (who would go on to create The Simpsons), that was shot by their father Homer in 1969. In the film Lisa recounts an adventure that she and Matt have in the woods. Homer Groening worked in advertising but found time to make [...]
item.content:encoded:
“The Story” is a charming short film starring Maggie, Lisa, and Matt Groening (who would go on to create The Simpsons), that was shot by their father Homer in 1969. In the film Lisa recounts an adventure that she and Matt have in the woods. Homer Groening worked in advertising but found time to make cartoons, write stories with his children, and make curious absurdist short films (see below). Matt talks about “The Story” and how he was influenced by Homer in this 2012 interview with Smithsonian Magazine. “The Story” can be purchased on DVD from A/V Geeks.

via Dangerous Minds

item.title: A Bicycle Trip, A Short Animation About the First Intentional Acid Trip Taken by Albert Hofmann in 1943
item.dc:creator: EDW Lynch
item.description: The 2007 animated short “A Bicycle Trip” recounts the fateful day in 1943 that Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann ingested a chemical compound he had synthesized—lysergic acid diethylamide, or LSD—thus becoming the first person to intentionally experience an acid trip (he had accidentally dosed himself with acid a few days prior). The animation was created by [...]
item.content:encoded:
The 2007 animated short “A Bicycle Trip” recounts the fateful day in 1943 that Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann ingested a chemical compound he had synthesized—lysergic acid diethylamide, or LSD—thus becoming the first person to intentionally experience an acid trip (he had accidentally dosed himself with acid a few days prior). The animation was created by Lorenzo Veracini, Nandini Nambiar, and Marco Avoletta.

via Open Culture

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Garrick Utley (1939-2014), Former News Anchor and Chief Foreign Correspondent
item.dc:creator: Lori Dorn
item.description: Garrick Utley, former news anchor and foreign correspondent, died on February 20, 2014 at the age of 74 at his home in New York City. He is survived by his wife Gertje. Over the years, Mr. Utley covered such extraordinary stories as the Warsaw Pact Invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, the 1973 Yom Kippur War [...]
item.content:encoded:
Garrick Utley, former news anchor and foreign correspondent, died on February 20, 2014 at the age of 74 at his home in New York City. He is survived by his wife Gertje.

Over the years, Mr. Utley covered such extraordinary stories as the Warsaw Pact Invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, the 1973 Yom Kippur War in 1973, the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and co-anchored the September 11 attacks in 2001. He also hosted the show “Meet the Press” and subbed in for Tom Brokaw on the “NBC Nightly News” many times. After he retired from television, Mr. Utley taugh Journalism at the State University of New York at Oswego.

Rest in Peace Mr. Utley.

via The New York Times

item.title: Artist Uses Sand to Create Ever-Changing Illustrations in Live Performances
item.dc:creator: EDW Lynch
item.description: Artist Jin Lee uses sand to make illustrations that he constantly changes and evolves in live performances. Lee uses his hands to make images in sand on a backlit panel. The images are captured by a camera and projected before an audience. This 2013 video depicts a 4-minute performance in which Lee recounts the early [...]
item.content:encoded:
Artist Jin Lee uses sand to make illustrations that he constantly changes and evolves in live performances. Lee uses his hands to make images in sand on a backlit panel. The images are captured by a camera and projected before an audience. This 2013 video depicts a 4-minute performance in which Lee recounts the early history of Earth in a series of sand art images.

photos via Jin Lee

via Koreus, Daily Picks and Flicks

item.title: Clever Girl Scout Does Brisk Business Selling Cookies Outside a San Francisco Cannabis Dispensary
item.dc:creator: EDW Lynch
item.description: On Monday 13-year-old Girl Scout Danielle Lei set up a table outside The Green Cross, a cannabis dispensary in San Francisco, and sold 117 boxes of Girl Scout cookies in 2 hours. Lei was accompanied by her mother, who had cleared the endeavor with the dispensary in advance. When contacted by Mashable, the Girl Scouts [...]
item.content:encoded:
On Monday 13-year-old Girl Scout Danielle Lei set up a table outside The Green Cross, a cannabis dispensary in San Francisco, and sold 117 boxes of Girl Scout cookies in 2 hours. Lei was accompanied by her mother, who had cleared the endeavor with the dispensary in advance. When contacted by Mashable, the Girl Scouts of Northern California said they had no problem with Lei’s endeavor, though the Girl Scouts of Colorado recently tweeted that they forbid Girl Scouts in their state from selling outside of a dispensary:

If you are wondering, we don't allow our Girl Scouts to sell cookies in front of marijuana shops or liquor stores/bars.

— Girl Scouts of Colo. (@GSColo) February 12, 2014

photos via The Green Cross

via Mashable

item.title: Hannah Hart and Mary Louise Parker Exchange Puns and Bake Brownies on ‘My Drunk Kitchen’
item.dc:creator: Lori Dorn
item.description: In this latest episode of “My Drunk Kitchen“, host Hannah Hart exchanges puns and bakes off-recipe brownies with special guest, actress Mary-Louise Parker (MLP). If we had just followed the box this would be a brownie without bananas, walnut and peanut butter. The best part of these oven babies is that they had a chance [...]
item.content:encoded:
In this latest episode of “My Drunk Kitchen“, host Hannah Hart exchanges puns and bakes off-recipe brownies with special guest, actress Mary-Louise Parker (MLP).

If we had just followed the box this would be a brownie without bananas, walnut and peanut butter. The best part of these oven babies is that they had a chance and you know what gave them that chance? Us and you (and you and you and you and that one in the corner). You can give something and somebody else a chance by going to omaze.com/weeds and helping a life that would have been destined for one thing be destined for something else entirely…and that something else entirely is delicious.

Hannah was referring to the opportunity to bake brownies with MLP and the cast of Weeds in an online raffle benefitting Hope North, an organization benefitting the young victims of Uganda’s civil war.

This is your chance to kick it with Mary-Louise Parker and the cast of Weeds. We’ll even let you bring a friend so the two of you can relive the highlights forever, and make your other friends green with envy. You’ll spend an unforgettable day baking brownies, enjoying a best-of-Weeds viewing marathon, and reminiscing about the good-old-days in Agrestic.

item.title: Conan O’Brien Helps Deliver a Special Valentine’s Day Bouquet on ‘Conan’
item.dc:creator: Rollin Bishop
item.description: On a recent episode of Conan, host Conan O’Brien helped create and deliver a very special Valentine’s Day bouquet to one lucky Mulberry Row florist customer’s special someone. Conan also informed the Mulberry Row workers about how he surprisingly had trouble getting a girl’s attention in his 20s. submitted via Laughing Squid Tips
item.content:encoded:
On a recent episode of Conan, host Conan O’Brien helped create and deliver a very special Valentine’s Day bouquet to one lucky Mulberry Row florist customer’s special someone. Conan also informed the Mulberry Row workers about how he surprisingly had trouble getting a girl’s attention in his 20s.

submitted via Laughing Squid Tips

item.title: Jerry Seinfeld Performs Standup as First Comedian on ‘The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon’
item.dc:creator: Rollin Bishop
item.description: Comedian Jerry Seinfeld recently performed standup on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon — the very first comedian to do so during Fallon’s tenure. He also discussed previously performing on The Tonight Show and the ways in which his style of parenting is different than the current generation’s.
item.content:encoded: Comedian Jerry Seinfeld recently performed standup on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon — the very first comedian to do so during Fallon’s tenure. He also discussed previously performing on The Tonight Show and the ways in which his style of parenting is different than the current generation’s.

item.title: Behind the Scenes at the U.S. Army Center of Military History
item.dc:creator: EDW Lynch
item.description: BuzzFeed recently toured the U.S. Army Center of Military History, a facility near Washington D.C. that houses a vast collection of art, artifacts, and documents relating to U.S. military history. Among the intriguing artifacts in the Center’s high security warehouse—an archive of firearms spanning the history of the U.S., uniforms of famous military figures, and [...]
item.content:encoded:
BuzzFeed recently toured the U.S. Army Center of Military History, a facility near Washington D.C. that houses a vast collection of art, artifacts, and documents relating to U.S. military history. Among the intriguing artifacts in the Center’s high security warehouse—an archive of firearms spanning the history of the U.S., uniforms of famous military figures, and the Army’s art collection. The art collection contains works commissioned by and donated to the Army as well as art seized during wars (the collection even includes original paintings by Hitler that were seized in World War II). The Center’s warehouse is not open to the public but a museum is in the works.

photos via BuzzFeed

item.title: OpenKnit, An Open-Source Knitting Machine That Uses Digital Files to Create Clothing
item.dc:creator: Rollin Bishop
item.description: OpenKnit is an open-source knitting machine that uses STL files, common in 3D printing, to fabricate clothing. Created at least in part by Gerard Rubio, OpenKnit was heavily inspired by the RepRap project, and uses the Knitic software for designs. Though OpenKnit is still in an early development stage, and requires some handmade steps, the [...]
item.content:encoded:
OpenKnit is an open-source knitting machine that uses STL files, common in 3D printing, to fabricate clothing. Created at least in part by Gerard Rubio, OpenKnit was heavily inspired by the RepRap project, and uses the Knitic software for designs.

Though OpenKnit is still in an early development stage, and requires some handmade steps, the ultimate goal is full automation. The full breakdown for the machine, including Arduino instructions, a step-by-step assembly manual, and a list of every component is avaiable on GitHub.

images via Gerard Rubio

via Boing Boing

item.title: Cat Slides Into Tiny Vertical Space Between Boxes While Chasing a A Toy

item.title: News Personality Bob Herzog Sings ‘Just Don’t Go’, A Parody of ‘Let It Go’ From Disney’s Animated Film ‘Frozen’
item.dc:creator: Rollin Bishop
item.description: News personality Bob Herzog, known for his “Dance Party Friday” tradition where he, well, dances on Friday, has posted a short clip from a news broadcast where he sings “Just Don’t Go”, a parody of “Let It Go” from Disney’s hit animated film Frozen. After having seen the phenomenal Disney film “Frozen” with his daughter [...]
item.content:encoded:
News personality Bob Herzog, known for his “Dance Party Friday” tradition where he, well, dances on Friday, has posted a short clip from a news broadcast where he sings “Just Don’t Go”, a parody of “Let It Go” from Disney’s hit animated film Frozen.

After having seen the phenomenal Disney film “Frozen” with his daughter twice and having heard her listen to songs from the movie many times more, Bob Herzog felt compelled to let his parody pen write “Just Don’t Go” to explain the plight of the Traffic Man in winter. There is a reason he doesn’t sing for a living.

via Tastefully Offensive

item.title: Player Achieves Lowest Possible Score in ‘Super Mario Bros.’
item.dc:creator: Rollin Bishop
item.description: YouTube user NotEntirelySure has posted a video of their run through the first Super Mario Bros. video game, originally for the Nintendo Entertainment System, where they earn the lowest score possible — 500 points — without continuing. This is only possible by not killing any enemies, gathering any coins, and intentionally running out the game’s [...]
item.content:encoded:
YouTube user NotEntirelySure has posted a video of their run through the first Super Mario Bros. video game, originally for the Nintendo Entertainment System, where they earn the lowest score possible — 500 points — without continuing. This is only possible by not killing any enemies, gathering any coins, and intentionally running out the game’s clock before finishing any given level. Other than speeding up the wait to run out the clock at the end of the level, no digital trickery was employed in the making of the run.

How tough is that jump in 8-1? Well, the timing of the liftoff, the duration of holding the jump button, and the timing of the wall jump are all frame perfect. NES games run at 60 frames per second, which means all the necessary inputs need to be timed within 1/60 of a second. In addition, the starting position before running I used not only has to be on the right pixel, but also the x sub-pixel has to fall within a certain range (technical stuff blah blah blah). In short, it’s a pretty annoying jump.

via Digg

item.title: Albuquerque Action Squad, An Unofficial Set of ‘Breaking Bad’ LEGO Minifigs
item.dc:creator: Rollin Bishop
item.description: Custom-designed LEGO company Citizen Brick produces a series of unofficial LEGO blocks, ranging from custom tiles for sets to specific minifigs, and their latest unofficial foray includes a pack of three minifigs inspired by hit television drama Breaking Bad called The Albuquerque Action Squad. The pack includes a Legal Defense Enthusiast, a Drug Dealing Enthusiast, [...]
item.content:encoded:
Custom-designed LEGO company Citizen Brick produces a series of unofficial LEGO blocks, ranging from custom tiles for sets to specific minifigs, and their latest unofficial foray includes a pack of three minifigs inspired by hit television drama Breaking Bad called The Albuquerque Action Squad.

The pack includes a Legal Defense Enthusiast, a Drug Dealing Enthusiast, and a Law Enforcement Enthusiast minifig. In other words, it includes a minifig of Saul Goodman, Jesse Pinkman, and Hank Schrader. The Albuquerque Action Squad is currently available on Citizen Brick.

images via Citizen Brick

via HiConsumption, The Awesomer
